[http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] Fascinating!  I think this pano is later than the HHT one due to various trees between the houses.  
I bet this pano is also by John Degotardi - do you remember which was his house on Peacock Point, Balmain?  Was it in Edwards St?

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: 1858 interactive map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-rm1272-sd&rgn=... 1867 interactive map - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview/?pi=nla.map-rm2685-sd&rgn=...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] Your question is timely, for I've only just acquired a rare book, John Fletcher, John Degotardi : Printer, publisher and photographer (Sydney : Book Collectors' Society of Australia, 1984). The house which was called "Feslenberg" (ie. rock mountain) [see Empire, Friday 1 December 1865, p. 1], was situated on John Street (later renamed Edward Street), Peacock Point, Balmain. The house was previously known as "Prospect Cottage" [see Empire, Saturday 14/09/1861, p. 1].
While the Degotardi house admittedly still enjoyed its prospect over the bay to Observatory Hill, its new name no doubt derived from the rocky, in fact even perilous cliff edge which abutted the Degotardis' garden. (Fletcher, p. 66)
The block of land Degotardi bought in 1859, lot 10, was "wedged between" (Fletcher, p. 65) Chape's Wharf and Edwin Beckmann, watchmaker, his immediate neighbour to the south on lot 9. Both lots commanded views of Observatory Hill (Fletcher, p. 48). 1888 map - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367035.html 1896 map - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/_zoomify/2008/D00663/a1367036.html And yes, it means this panoramic view was taken perhaps literally from his back garden, or very close to it, and is almost certainly by John Degotardi, a specialist in panoramic views. Google Maps Street View: maps.google.com.au/maps?q=balmain&hl=en&ll=-33.85...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/albumView.aspx?acmsID=420980&amp... - just for interest check out this wonderful Degotardi panorama taken from McMahon's point, which ranges from Dawes Point/Miller's Point to Goat Island...looking at the buildings etc around the observatory, the McMahon's Point panorama looks to have been taken at a later date than this equally wonderful panorama...I gather that 'McMahon's House' which accompanies the McMahon's Point panorama, was the house built by Maurice McMahon in 1864 (per Wikipedia)...in about the mid 1870s it was purchased by George St draper John Davies, who named it 'Leddicott'...which suggests the McMahon's Point panorama might have been taken in the period 1864-ca.1875... Balmain from Miller's Point ?1870s - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=420904 ; acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=420903

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] That's a great pano - it must be later than this one as it shows the 'six-house terrace' on Peacock Point.  Must try to find a date for that terrace  ...

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: Here we go - the 'six-house terrace' - "Nos 7-17 [Edward Street] make up an early stone Regency terrace (1870) of six called 'Harbour View Terrace' built by developer Francis Smith Jnr." from - www.walkingcoastalsydney.com.au/brochures/documents/HC201... There was even a "Davidson" birth at 'Harbour View Terrace' in October 1870 - trove.nla.gov.au/ndp/del/article/13212718

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content:
Which implies this pano is before 1870 (and after 1860, see St Georges Church note in No.4).

So far ...

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/pellethepoet] ; [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia] fantastic work on the Degotardi pics...both here and elsewhere! acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/album/albumView.aspx?acmsID=420926&amp... - just for interest, see pic 203 (on page 23) in this American & Australasian Photographic Co album, titled 'Darling Street, Balmain' ...it's a similar view...? taken perhaps a little earlier than the Degotardi panorama...it might be possible to use this pic to establish more precisely where Degotardi stood to take his panorama...the SLNSW have a date of ca. 1871 for the album, but I suspect that many of the pics it contains would have been taken in the 1860s... [later]...I've just noticed the windmill in pic 203...out on the end of the point acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=404899 ; acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=411357 I gather we also see it in these pics acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemLarge.aspx?itemID=412945 this looks to be taken somewhat later...it shows a few of the buildings we see in Degotardi's panorama no.1 pic from the eastern side...

comment.author: 47201412@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/51979177@N02] I've been quietly working on that c.1871 album over the last few days and have identified about a dozen of the pics. [http://www.flickr.com/photos/beachcomberaustralia/] has done a few too. There are plenty more to identify but I'll send you a list so that we don't duplicate our efforts!
